div1.p: Consulate General of the United States Monrovia Jan 11/87
Trouble in the Repulic of Liberia.
Disloyalty of the native tribes at Half-Carally-Action of the Twentieth Legislature. Peace or war at the will of the President.
Consulate General of the U.S. Manrovia Jan 11th/87
Hon. T. F. Bayard, Secty of State Washington D. C.

Sir: I have the honor respectfully to inform you that there has been considerable trouble in the Southeast Extermity of the Conty of Maryland which is one of the Counties of the Republic of Liberia, with the tribes called the Grebo dwelling at Half-Carally: The Trouble arises

arises thus-- the natives at Half-Cavally refuse to be loyal to the government in the payment of import duties. They feel that they should not be made to pay on merchandise foreign adventurers and merchants bring into their port of entry nor do they feel they should pay on what they have imported into their own domain. The difficulties existing there have raised the feelings of loyal citizens very much--in so much that the setting of the Twentieth Legislature of the

the Republic steps were taken to quailtheir unwarrented privileges either by treaty of peace or by war as the President of the Republic sees fit. I have not yet fully been able to get into the trust of the difficulties existing owing to the irreguality of the maid steamers stopping at this port; but only here and there an outline I have been able to obtain, war I believe is inevitable. I shall inform the department of future steps taken by this government. I hope in my next
I am Sir your obedient servant
Samuel S. Sevier Acting U.S. Consul General.
